No Impairment Noted, Person is within normal cognitive limits; Additional testing may be of use to detect subtle deficits, if any. If you have a concern, please see a psychologist or your healthcare provider
Person is diminished but functional, additional testing is likely warranted. Please see a psychologist or your healthcare provider.

Moderate Cognitive Impairment, additional testing is strongly encouraged. This person may have a dementia disorder or another neurological or psychological concern. Please see a psychologist or your healthcare provider

Serious Cognitive Impairment of Possible Organic origin, additional testing is strongly encouraged. Person likely is experiencing a dementia like disorder or another neurological concern. please see a psychologist or your healthcare provider.

W. Steven Saunders, Psy.D. is a Licensed Psychologist and an Associate Lecturer at the University of Central Florida. He is the staff Neuropsychologist for the local hospital. Dr. Saunders maintains a private practice in Lake County, Florida. He can be contacted at wstevensaunders@gmail.com. His website is CentralFloridaPsychology.com.

The Dementia Test is designed to be given verbally from one person to another. The administrator, the person giving the test, asks the questions. The test taker, the person taking the test, answers the questions. You, the administrator, should not show the screen to the test taker. Generally, the questions are very common sense and easy to give. Read the questions and mark each correct answer with a point by click the buttons provided.

For ORIENTATION, ATTENTION, IMMEDIATE RECALL, LANGUAGE, FLUIDITY of SPEECH / RECALL, CALCULATION, SHORT TERM MEMORY (Delayed Recall), Please Ask the questions, check the box for 1 point after each correct answer.

JUDGMENT: Please Ask the questions, check the box for 1 point after each correct answer. Answers should demonstrate the appropriate action that would solve the problem. For Example, to the question, “What would you do if you came home and the toilet had backed up and water was running into the house?” , The answer should be “Turn the water off and call a plumber” or “Call for help and turn the water off.” Answers that do not demonstrate the need for help or that the water should be turned off, should not be counted. For the question, “What would you do if you found yourself stranded in the Dallas Airport with only $1 in your pocket?” The answer should be “Use the dollar to call for help. Or ask for help from (some appropriate authority” Answers that question why they are in Dallas or “this would never happen to me” etc., should not be scored. Answers that are confused or incoherent should not be scored correct.

ABSTRACT REASONING: Please Ask the questions, check the box for 1 point after each correct answer. 1. A quarter and a nickel are both (Coins or Money) A Watch and a Ruler are both (Measurement instruments or ways to measure time and distance). Answers that are not abstract or simply define each term should not be scored correct.

About This Tool: This is a screening instrument based upon current psychology and neuroscience research as well as the extensive clinical experience of the author. A pilot study (Saunders, W. S. (2010). The Consice Cognitive Status Examination: Mental Status Examination with a Smart-Phone Application. The Florida Psychologist Vol. 60, No. 3, pp. 15-22) was conducted to determine the reliabilty and validity of this tool. 

This tool demonstrated reliability and validity when compared to other mental status examination screening instruments that measure broad cognitive abilities. This tool is meant as a beginning screening test to start a conversation with your loved ones. Give the test with an attitude of compassion and love. You will get better results that way. You should consider consulting an experienced professional in conjunction with a physical examination, a biopsychosocial history, and other psychological, cognitive, and neuropsychological testing for the most accurate diagnosis. This screening instrument should never be relied upon as the sole basis for making any determination about a person. This screening instrument should be used as a general guide for helping to make a competent clinical judgment within the context of a full Neuropsychogical examination.
